question: B 05 (a)
sols_html:
The first and second entry of \(P^k \begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\) give the probability that, after k steps, the random walker is in location 1 and location 2, respectively, when the random walker starts in location 1. Therefore we calculate

\[\begin{aligned} P^{2} \begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}1/2 & 1/4 \\1/2 & 3/4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2\end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

which tells us that the probability of being in state 1 is 1/2.

statement_html:
We are given the following transition matrix for a random walk

\[\begin{aligned} P = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1/2 \\ 1 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

What is the probability that a walker starting in location 1 is in location 1 after 2 steps?
